body: I've been thinking this as well. Most users will be better off running the latest version, always. Replacing the in-GUI upgrade functionality with an automatic background upgrade (disabled by a checkbox in settings for those who really want to) seems sane to me.
If this is implemented, the click to upgrade option should still be available for those that opt out of the automatic upgrade.

Some questions:

As the auto upgrades can strike at random, it makes sense to emit an event indicating that we are about to restart. Now at the UI, we could catch that event and show a modal while the restart is in progress and then refresh the page.

But the issue is that the user might be in a middle of something (for example editing ignores), and we don't want to suddenly destroy all of his work by doing a refresh.

I guess it's fine to actually restart syncthing as all the state is in the browser, not in the application, but then again, the underlying application has changed, so how do you know that the action you are doing is an action the application supports?

The current way I've done it is basically it closes any modals that were open, and gives you a new modal with a 10 seconds countdown which you have the opportunity to cancel (or you can just click refresh yourself). 

This seems to work, but I am starting to think that perhaps _fighting windmills_ and trying to tackle problems that do not exist?

Also, in the above scenario, perhaps if no modals are currently open, I could perhaps just blindly refresh without any prior notification to the user?
Or perhaps it should be a non-cancel'able modal which is shown for 2 seconds to give an indication of what the hell is happening?
How about you alert the user in their browser that a restart is scheduled in five minutes, press X to cancel.

This doesn't solve the issue of:

> I guess it's fine to actually restart syncthing as all the state is in the browser, not in the application, but then again, the underlying application has changed, so how do you know that the action you are doing is an action the application supports?

Which basically implies, if you are editing ignores, and the underlying application has already updated itself, how do you know that the new application actually supports editing ignores?
You find out when you submit it :)

+1 to having this functionality, optional and on by default, with a warning a few minutes before it happens, and only when idle.

2 things to think about:
A- Coordination with installer scripts:  What if the underlying infrastructure also handles updates? How to avoid issues?  Ex.: F-Droid installs 0.9.x which then self-updates to 0.9.y, but F-Droid doesn't know and didn't do other stuff it should be doing.

B- The future introduction of Long Term Support (LTS) versions.
The current release cycle of Syncthing is very fast. This is great and expected given the age of the project. Each release brings new features, bug fixes and perhaps security fixes. However, as the user base grows, and Syncthing gets integrated in other apps (I myself have plans in this direction), there will be a desire for a more stable branch, which has just security fixes (and perhaps critical bug fixes) but not new features. Certainly not new features which have the potential to introduce regressions.

Here is a good explanation of why & how to have LTS versions: https://info.tiki.org/Version+Lifecycle 

A key benefit of LTS is that it makes it easier to make big changes in the future. There could (will!) also be a desire in the future to update the protocol. I know it's "supposed" to always be backward compatible once 1.0 comes out, but it's nice to keep our options open.
https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/protocol/PROTOCOL.md

There very well may be a requirement in the future that all nodes be of version 2.0 for the fancy new stuff to work. 

Now, back to auto-updates. If & when LTS versions are introduced, there should be a way to select either regular releases (new features) or LTS (security fixes mostly).

Best regards,

M ;-)
The Android version already has updates completely disabled via compile flag, because neither Google nor F-Droid allow self-updating apps ;)
How about avoiding any problems with warnings altogether and only updating upon exit, or next launch? There could additionally be a sensible prompt to "Upgrade now", like there currently is.

I wouldn't worry too much... Perhaps it'd be worth postponing a restart to a new version until 1) we are not in the middle of a sync operation and 2) we haven't received a REST query in 60 seconds or something like that. That's idle enough from my point of view.

> LTS

Syncthing is still in beta. Arguably it's used widely enough that we should be in 1.0, and we're already worrying a fair bit about compatibility in new releases. But I want to be super duper sure with sugar on top that we won't need to change the protocol for quite a while when we actually say "1.0"...

Having the ability to easily turn off auto-updates will also be important for those of us running Syncthing in Docker containers. An update will only update the container as long as it's running. It can't change the base image.

When upgrading in Windows, and the prevous version, syncthing.exe.old, still exists, syncthing fails to upgrade citing "cannot rename a file when a file exists" or similar. I keep meaning to fill a bug against this but haven't gotten round to it. Maybe it's worth looking at before the autoupdate is put in place?

This has been fixed a5e3317e28cfef2718540166cac509696c4368d9 which seems to be there since v0.9.16. 
Which version are you running, and do you have a log of when it fails?
I hadn't realised it had been fixed, sorry. I've been manually removing the .old each time - I will watch the next update and check.
If you manually managed to remove .old, then it shouldn't be failing in the first place to be honest.

Guys, is there a way to disable it? (during the build step)

With '-tags noupgrade' it's still tries to update :(
`11:34:44: Automatic upgrade: upgrade unsupported`
There's a checkbox among the settings, but that's a bug. When built without upgrades, it should not run at all. (Neither should the checkbox be available, so that's something to fix)
@calmh should I open new bug report?
